RT @kschwabable : Leaked audio from more than 80 internal TikTok meetings shows that China-based employees of ByteDance have repeatedly accessed nonpublic data about US TikTok users. “Everything is seen in China,” said a member of TikTok’s Trust and Safety department in one Sept 2021 meeting. https://t.co/UdTok0tTtC
RT @kadiagoba : The Jan 6 House Committee just announced the fourth hearing next Tuesday, June 21 at 1:00pm

Shortly before publication of this story, TikTok published a blog post saying that it has changed the “default storage location of US user data” and that today, “100% of US user traffic is being routed to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure.”

https://t.co/jwNZdVQEbq https://t.co/EdMRSZdFvu

ByteDance is currently working on "Project Texas," an effort to make sure “protected” data can no longer flow from the US into China. Most situations where China-based staff were accessing US user data was in service of halting this data access, the recordings show.

Concerns over China-based employees of ByteDance, which owns TikTok, accessing Americans' personal data is part of what inspired former president Donald Trump to threaten to ban the app in the United States.

https://t.co/jwNZdVQEbq

“Everything is seen in China,” said a member of TikTok’s Trust and Safety department in a September 2021 meeting. In another September meeting, a director referred to one Beijing-based engineer as a “Master Admin” who “has access to everything.” 

https://t.co/jwNZdVQEbq

Audio from more than 80 meetings contains 14 statements from nine different TikTok employees indicating that engineers in China had access to US data between September 2021 and January 2022, at the very least.

https://t.co/jwNZdVQEbq

US TikTok user data has been repeatedly accessed from China, leaked audio from 80 internal meetings reveals.

To find out how private equity giant KKR runs its group homes, we had to do some serious digital sleuthing.

Here’s how we did it.
https://t.co/Y51RhyxdUF
KKR’s ownership of BrightSpring offers a cautionary tale about what can happen when a private equity firm’s playbook is brought to bear on exceptionally vulnerable Americans. https://t.co/lrXMH5bCpV
Touting its financial success, KKR has announced plans to take BrightSpring public — a development that could yield massive returns for investors and executives. https://t.co/2Gk7iR3gY1

KKR and BrightSpring declined to meet with BuzzFeed News to discuss these issues on the record. Instead, they issued statements disagreeing with our findings, calling them a “grossly misleading narrative.” https://t.co/2Gk7iR3gY1 https://t.co/op70LHUWNr

KKR’s handpicked board of directors approved plans to take out loans to buy other companies. BrightSpring was left to pay more than $135 million in interest a year — money that might otherwise have helped improve conditions in the homes. https://t.co/2Gk7iR3gY1

Some nurses quit because they feared that working for the company amid such conditions might cost them their licenses, according to internal company emails. A nurse said some clients could die. https://t.co/2Gk7iR3gY1

Local managers pleaded that they couldn’t keep the homes safely staffed on what BrightSpring was willing to pay. They said BrightSpring executives pressured them to keep accepting new residents anyway. https://t.co/2Gk7iR3gY1 https://t.co/qbdyxb7Rme

Perry McAfee, who oversaw about 60 group homes around Houston, said the company “was not focused on quality of services, but on the revenue generated each month.” https://t.co/2Gk7iR3ONz https://t.co/xLF3PN2K2g

KKR focused on expanding the business despite crises in dozens of group homes. Nurses and caretakers quit in droves. A state stopped the company from taking new residents. Some of the most vulnerable patients suffered and died. https://t.co/2Gk7iR3gY1

Sarah Bryner, research director at the Center for Responsive Politics, said the challenge posed by crypto donations is primarily one of enforcement. 

The FEC is “not gonna go hunt down a donation worth $500 when there are bigger fish to fry,” Bryner said. https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB

In some ways, crypto donations pose similar challenges to donations made in cash. But the FEC prohibits cash contributions to campaigns in amounts over $100, and no such limit exists for crypto. https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB

Aarika Rhodes, Congressional candidate who accepts donations via BitPay and the Lightning Network, said that while the anonymity of crypto can benefit private individuals, “I think we should have full transparency about where [candidates] get their money.” https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB

Rev. Wendy Hamilton, a progressive candidate for Congress who takes donations via BitPay, Coinbase, and the Lightning Network, said taking crypto isn’t so different from taking donations of fiat currency. https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB https://t.co/I1s76EGmC8

Candidates that BuzzFeed News spoke to expressed the desire to be fully transparent about their campaign donors. But none seemed uniquely concerned about the verification challenges posed by crypto. https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB

This poses the risk that crypto donors could engage in fraudulent or otherwise illegal giving, leading campaigns to fail to report the cryptocurrency given to them, whether negligently or nefariously. https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB

Candidates with BitPay and Coinbase wallets had to prove their identity to the platform when they signed up. But the people sending money to candidates’ wallets aren’t always required to do the same. https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB

Platforms like BitPay and Coinbase intentionally anonymize user wallets to make transactions hard to trace. That’s why campaigns must rely on crypto donors truthfully filling out a simple web form with few mechanisms to ensure it’s accurate. https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB

The Federal Election Commission requires candidates to collect and disclose donors’ names, addresses, and employers, which they can normally do by matching a donor’s name to the name on a check or the address on a credit card. https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB

In preparation for the 2022 midterm elections, more candidates than ever have begun accepting donations in cryptocurrency. 

But it’s hard to verify that donors are who they say? https://t.co/e6UM0nwjQB

During NCIA's rollout, in 2017, five terrorism incidents in the UK resulted in 40 killed and more than 800 injured. The deadliest was a bombing at the end of an Ariana Grande concert in the Manchester Arena, which killed 22. https://t.co/R2AfPSAPHL

But the program, meant to be a searchable national database of all known information about potential violent extremists, was plagued by crashes, blackouts, and data duplications, according to sources and documents seen by BuzzFeed News. https://t.co/R2AfPSAPHL

RT @richardjnieva : New from me and @Amannama: We wrote about Worldcoin, Sam Altman's eyeball-scanning crypto startup. The company's distributors, which sign people up using a mysterious device called an Orb, have faced arrests, harassment and late payments. 
https://t.co/3oAkuFtXLe

Responding to criticism that Worldcoin entered less developed nations with Silicon Valley hubris, Blania said the company does a “very big legal deep dive” before launching in new countries.

https://t.co/S3UQtUGR0g https://t.co/lEBo2mDXJ2

Many of Worldcoin’s operators have been deployed in poor countries in Africa and Asia, where users who had their eyes scanned have now sent hundreds of outraged messages to Orb operators demanding the money they were promised. 

https://t.co/S3UQtUGR0g https://t.co/lbuQSgDhLr

Meanwhile the people operating the Orbs have faced arrests, harassment, late payment, and a changing wage structure that they say makes the work financially unfeasible.

https://t.co/S3UQtUGR0g

Worldcoin CEO Alex Blania strongly pushed back on the suggestion that Worldcoin’s purpose was to harvest the world’s eyeballs in return for a cryptocurrency that may turn out to be worthless. 

https://t.co/S3UQtUGR0g https://t.co/sLgNiHVx6U

The Orb doesn't capture just irises. It also measures people's temperature, maps out their face, and takes video and images of their body, face, and eyes, according to Worldcoin’s data consent form.

https://t.co/S3UQtUGR0g

But a BuzzFeed News investigation has found that Worldcoin is wrestling with issues including managing its Orb operators and concerns the company is using its yet-to-be-launched cryptocurrency as a means to collect biometrics. 

https://t.co/S3UQtUGR0g

The centerpiece of Worldcoin's effort to share crypto with the world's population is the Orb, a silver sphere with a robotic voice, that scans irises to keep track of who already got their cut.

https://t.co/S3UQtUGR0g

Worldcoin wants to lift millions out of poverty by giving everyone free crypto — as long as they scan their eyes into a device called the Orb. But with its token yet to launch, participants say they feel robbed.

Ashton often hears women describe their bodies using words like “mutilated” and “not whole.” Scars or the absence of nipples can remind patients about their own powerlessness in the face of cancer, so these tattoos can represent moving forward. https://t.co/9TaAFAatNN https://t.co/R1D0nx8MXz

Kathleen Ashton, PhD, director of behavioral health for the Cleveland Clinic Breast Center, said that body image issues are common in women with breast cancer who can face everything from hair loss to weight gain to scarring. https://t.co/9TaAFAatNN

At these appointments, there is crying. There is hugging. There are also opportunities to be creative. One woman said her breast cancer had broken her heart. To commemorate what she’d lost, she asked her tattoo artist to make her areola in the shape of a heart.

Vinnie Myers, Wymer’s tattoo artist, estimates that he’s done tattoos for about 12,000 women over the past 20 years. He said the feedback he hears from clients the most is that they finally feel like themselves again, or that they feel whole. https://t.co/9TaAFAatNN https://t.co/gjX3y7Kfz4

Nipple reconstruction surgery can cost thousands of dollars, while nipple tattoos usually cost less than $1,000. A 2018 study found that breast cancer survivors with nipple tattoos were happier with their breasts and reported better sexual and psychosocial well-being.

The appointment didn’t last more than an hour and a half, but the effects were both striking and permanent. Looking at her tattoos for the first time was, Wymer said, like seeing the final period at the end of a long chapter. https://t.co/9TaAFAatNN https://t.co/aL9Pgs1qLB

In 2017, through a cancer support group, Wymer heard about a tattoo artist who specializes in photorealistic 3D nipple tattoos. During a visit to his shop, the artist mapped out a location for her tattoos and explained how he’d camouflage the bumps created by her surgeon.

After the multi-surgery reconstruction of her breasts, she felt some of her confidence return. The surgeon had created a small bump atop each reconstructed breast to represent a nipple, but it was still unsettling to see “blank mounds'' on her chest. https://t.co/9TaAFAatNN

Carole Wymer was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2011. After doctors found a second tumor behind her first, they recommended both her breasts be removed. 

She was going to lose an element of her body, which she now realized felt like part of her identity. https://t.co/9TaAFAatNN https://t.co/A6rDHr9pDa

• How can you manage skin picking and get help?

There’s no single way a doctor may approach treating someone for skin picking disorder. Awareness of the condition is still growing, and the first step is to avoid feelings of shame.

https://t.co/nl9awGrweV https://t.co/1wncrA2fZr

Aaron Jeanfrancois started posting about their skin picking recovery on TikTok. He is inspired to spread awareness among people who are not white women – who are studied more often – as symptoms can show differently on nonwhite bodies.

But an otherwise little-known community is speaking up: Advocacy organizations, bots, apps, TikTokers, and Instagram accounts are spreading awareness about skin picking disorder.

https://t.co/nl9awGrweV

People with dermatillomania who spoke with BuzzFeed News said the pandemic exacerbated their anxiety and depression, leading them to double down on their behaviors in search of some form of relief.

https://t.co/nl9awGrweV

• Why can it take years to get a diagnosis?

Jennifer Hollander, a nurse practitioner at the Beverly Hills Center for Plastic & Laser Surgery, says patients rarely know they have skin picking disorder when they come to her. https://t.co/J10gLIO8gF
Skin picking is a common way for someone to deal with difficult emotions if they are already in recovery from another mental illness. One emotional regulator replaces another. https://t.co/dcA7jctC86

• What is it like to have skin picking disorder?

It goes far beyond popping pimples or removing dry skin; it can cause conspicuous lesions on the body. People affected often miss out on normal life or suffer emotional distress because of it.

https://t.co/nl9awGrweV https://t.co/2M401oJ6T1

• Why do people pick their skin?

According to Lauren McKeaney, CEO and founder of @PickingMeFdn, triggers depend on the person but can be anything from a stressful day to a comment about your appearance.

https://t.co/nl9awGrweV

Skin picking disorder, or dermatillomania, is a mental illness related to obsessive compulsive disorder that involves repeatedly picking at skin on the body as a way to handle emotional distress. It affects as many as 1 in 20 people. https://t.co/TSsTwQUmYn

Jaylin Scott picked at her skin for months, causing her intense physical and emotional pain. When she found videos on TikTok about people struggling with the same thing, they made her feel seen.

https://t.co/nl9awGrweV

While people who are unhoused have been behind a number of attacks recently, “homeless New Yorkers are far more likely to be victims of violent crime than perpetrators,” said Jacquelyn Simone, policy director for the Coalition for the Homeless in New York. https://t.co/00GwXbg6nq

In response to pervasive bias against people experiencing homelessness, efforts have been made to revise federal hate crime laws to include homeless status as a protected class but those proposals have not yet been approved.

https://t.co/00GwXbg6nq

There were at least 1,852 reported violent attacks on unhoused people by suspects who were not homeless from 1999 to 2019, including “murder, beatings, rape, and mutilations,” according to the National Coalition for the Homeless. Many more go unreported.

In a joint statement, New York Mayor Eric Adams and DC Mayor Muriel Bowser said, “The rise in gun violence has shaken all of us and it is particularly horrible to know that someone is out there deliberately doing harm to an already vulnerable population.”

https://t.co/00GwXbg6nq

Recently, five people experiencing homelessness in New York and Washington, DC, were shot, two fatally. These incidents are not uncommon, rather part of a larger routine of violence against an already vulnerable population.

https://t.co/00GwXbg6nq

In January 2020, 580,466 people experienced homelessness across the US, according to federal data. The data from 2021 is incomplete, as many programs did not do full counts of unsheltered people (who live in parks, streets, and vehicles) due to the pandemic.

The risk of homelessness is growing as protections brought on by the pandemic are set to end. And as more people are experiencing homelessness, the more at risk they are of being attacked while unhoused.
